title: Volkswagen Is Not A New British Petroleum: Buy Into The Phoenix
content:
The recent scandal with Volkswagen's (VLKAY) was really a shock to me. Just to remind readers: Volkswagen has been cheating on American pollution tests during the period of 2008-2015 and was caught red-handed by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. Now there is a high probability of paying the largest fine the automobile industry has ever seen - about $18B, or circa €16B. You can read more about it here . 
 
However, the terrible reality is not the multi-billion dollar fine but, in fact, the tremendous blow to the company's reputation. Different countries (EU, including Italy, Switzerland, Norway, Russia, etc.) have announced their intention to investigate whether more than 11 million vehicles all over the world have defeat software fraud. If they make Volkswagen recall all these cars, it may cost the company nearly the same dollar amount as the potential penalty to the U.S. government. Moreover, many customers, especially the members of Greenpeace (see picture above), did not like the mere fact that Volkswagen was involved in this scandal. 
 
Consequently, there is no surprise that investors are in a state of panic. The company's share price has fallen by more than 35% during the two days after the initial announcement. Taking this into account, the capital gain on the stock is now at 0% over the last five years. This means that the five-year gains have been practically destroyed at once over the last week.
